(1) In the past, there was a bhiká¹£u who was intelligent and wise. At that time, he was gravely ill. His disciples asked:

He replied:ğŸ”½Not yet;
I have not yet returned.
They asked:
The Venerable's path is lofty and his fame is far-reaching. Why haven't you attained it?
The Venerable said:
I have already attained the two fruits of frequent rebirth, but I have not yet attained the third.
They asked:
Having already attained frequent rebirth, what obstacles prevent you from attaining the state of a true person?
He replied:

If you wish to see Maitreya Buddha, at the time of the three assemblies, 280 koá¹­is of people will attain sagehood, and the bodhisattvas will be innumerable. Maitreya TathÄgata will have a huge body, 160 zhang tall. The people of that land will all have the color of peach blossoms, and the people will all live for 84,000 years. The land will be flat and even, with food and clothing coming naturally. The land of JambudvÄ«pa will be 300,000 li wide and long.
If you wish to see this, do not attain sagehood.
At the time of Maitreya Buddha, the two foremost disciples will be called Za Shi and Shu Shu. If you wish to see them, do you know what they will be like?
The disciple asked again:
Where did you hear this?
The preceptor replied:
I heard it from the Buddha's sutras.
The disciple said:
The suffering of birth and death, if Maitreya has a different method, should we go and wait for it?
He replied:
Are the six pÄramitÄs, four equalities, four kinds of kindness, and four noble truths different?ğŸ”½He replied:
He replied:ğŸ”½No, I do not.
If they are all the same, with no difference between this and that, why wait any longer?
Now, having received the Buddha's kindness, I will return to Maitreya. I can also attain liberation without having to wait for him.
The preceptor said:
Stop!
You should leave now. I will contemplate.
As soon as the disciple left, before he even reached the door, he had already become a true person.
The disciple returned and said:
What is it?
The master said:
You have already become a true person.
The disciple bowed and said:
In the time it took to say 'tsk tsk,' you have already attained fruition.

(2) Once there was a bhiká¹£u who attained concentration. When wild fire burned, he was not burned. People saw him and thought he was a ghost, so they chopped at him, but the sword broke and did not enter.
Because his mind was focused, it did not enter, and because he was gentle, he was not burned.
There was a person who attained concentration. A disciple called him to eat, but he was unaware. The disciple then pulled his arm, and the arm extended a length of ten feet.
The disciple was frightened and took hold of it, fearing that it could not be untied. He untied it.
When the master woke up from meditation, he suffered from pain in his arm and asked the disciple, who explained as such.
The master said:
You did not know how to wake me up, and you broke my arm.
A person who attains concentration is soft and tender like cotton, and it is the same in the mother's womb.
(3) In the past, in the country of Kasmira, there was a bodhisattva. When he was born, the earth shook greatly, and his parents were all startled.
At that time, there was a true person who bowed his head to the ground and made offerings of flower canopies.

Later, he grew up, left home, and became enlightened and wise. However, he was often unrestrained and did not have the liberation of the Dharma. What he said caused those who heard it to attain the Way.
At that time, there were two people who became monks together. They guarded the precepts and were pure for many years, but their minds were not enlightened.
A celestial spirit said to them:
There is a bhiká¹£u in that country who has converted many people.
The two then went to the old place to invite him back.

At that time, this bhiká¹£u had an affair with a prostitute in that country. The two sought to see him. One entered first, paid respects, sat back, and the prostitute deliberately lay down, upright and extremely beautiful. Single-mindedly listening to the sÅ«tra without any other thoughts, he immediately attained the path and bowed before leaving.
He then sent another to pay respects, inquire, sit and listen. Seeing the lying prostitute, he thought:
This person is defiled and untrustworthy, suffering in vain from coming from afar.
He then abandoned it and went outside.
The bhiká¹£u said:
Why are you so worried? Do you have wrong views?
He said:
You have deceived us, enduring hardships over a long distance.
The bhiká¹£u said:
You are greatly mistaken.

A student of the Dharma should only focus the mind on listening and receiving wisdom and understanding. How can one criticize right and wrong, giving rise to evil thoughts oneself, causing nothing to be attained?
He then straightened his mind and went together to listen to the sutra, and attained the path of the stream-enterer.
One attained arhatship, and the teacher prepared a feast and returned to his home country.
Later, the teacher served as the abbot and extensively used the Sangha's property, indulging in licentious entertainment to excess.
The monks discussed expelling him, but a real person said:
Do not expel him yet!
Although he uses the Sangha's property, he is able to convert and guide many people.
So they stopped and did not expel him.
His relatives visited and said:
Your former disciple can go and beg for the various people's property.
He then went to that country, obtained many treasures, and returned to repay the Sangha twofold.

(4) In the past, there was a worthy who upheld the Dharma with diligence. He fell ill and suddenly passed away. His wife wailed and lamented, feeling that life was meaningless. After the cremation, they collected his bones and buried them. Having finished that, they neglected the sutras and did not set up incense and lamps. The family was wealthy, and on the first and fifteenth of every month, they slaughtered and prepared food. They gathered at the grave, cried, and wailed, feeling grief-stricken and heartbroken.
The deceased monk's precepts and virtue finally ascended to heaven. The heavenly eye saw from afar and pitied his foolishness, so he became a child herding a cow by the side.
The cow suddenly died, and the child cried out. He cut grass and put it in front of the cow, comforting it to eat. He also beat it to make it get up. He cried facing it like this all day long.
The people wondered and laughed, and they all went to scold and ask:
Whose child are you?
When the cow dies, you should tell your family. What's the use of crying?
Don't you know that the cow is dead?
He said:
I am not foolish.
As long as the dead cow is still here, there is still hope;
Your father died early. Even if you set up a hundred kinds of food and cry together, how would the burnt bones know?
The crowd heard and suddenly understood.
He said:
I was originally your father. I received the Buddha's teachings and was reborn in the heavens. I came here to enlighten you.
He then returned to his heavenly body and said, If you want to be like me, you must diligently practice the path and make offerings.
He suddenly disappeared.

His wife and children returned home, and with diligence, precepts, virtue, and generosity, they rescued everyone, no longer worrying, and all attained the path and were reborn in the heavens at the same time.
(5) In the ocean, there was a country named Sihe Die, which produced many precious treasures but only lacked molasses.

At that time, a merchant brought more than five hundred carts of molasses, thinking of offering it to the king, and the reward he would receive would certainly be greater than selling it. He then placed the molasses at the gate of the king's palace and explained his purpose.
In this way, for days and months, no one asked about it. He became angry and said:
That king is also a human, and I am also a human. Our eyes, ears, nose, mouth, and four elements are all the same. Yet I cannot get to see him or speak with him.
Why is this?
It is because the king's blessings and virtue surpass those of others.
I too shall make merit and cause the king to come to me without realizing it.

At that time, he went to become a monk, offered honey to the Three Jewels, sought a quiet place to contemplate suffering, emptiness, and non-self, and before half of it was completed, his mind was liberated without bondage and attained the six spiritual powers. Those who accomplished arhatship without moving from one place, the earth trembled, and the gods of Indra and the heavens came to offer congratulations. Then the gods of Indra and the heavens all descended, made obeisance, and assisted him in his joy.
The bhiká¹£u asked the god Indra:
What do you all do in the heavens?
He replied:

In the heavens there are four pleasure gardens, three places are for the five desires, and one place is for morality and virtue. In it, sometimes they discuss the noble scriptures of the Buddha, or sometimes they discuss the diligent and law-abiding people of the four groups in the world.
The bhiká¹£u said:
Do you discuss the law-abiding people as being of one kind, or are there depths and shallows?
The god Indra said:
The good people all say that since the Buddha entered nirvana, there have been three people whom the gods discuss and never abandon.
The bhiká¹£us said:
Who are they?
May the Heavenly Emperor tell me one by one.
The Heavenly Emperor said:
In the country of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a person who became a Å›ramaá¹‡a and made a vow, saying:
'I will walk and pace back and forth, and will not lie down to rest until I attain arhatship.'
Thus, he walked and paced back and forth day and night, his feet became wounded and blood flowed, and hundreds of birds chased and pecked at him. After three years, he attained the Way;
The gods praised him and none did not revere him.
There was a person in the country of RÄjagá¹›ha who also became a Å›ramaá¹‡a. He spread grass to make a mat and sat upon it, and made a vow, saying:
'I will not attain the Way and will not rise.'

But when he wanted to sleep, he had a person make an eight-inch awl. When he became sleepy, he would stab his two thighs with it. Because of the pain from the wounds, he did not sleep. Within one year, he attained arhatship;
The gods also exclaimed that it was unprecedented.
There was also a person in the country of KoÅ›ala who became a Å›ramaá¹‡a. He stayed in a steep and dangerous stone chamber in the mountains, and no one could come and go there.

At that time, MÄra PÄpÄ«yÄn saw his diligence and transformed himself into a water buffalo, bellowing and butting in front of the bhiká¹£u, wanting to touch him. The bhiká¹£u was very afraid and thought:
A buffalo cannot reach this place. Why is this?
Could it be the work of MÄra?
He then said:
Are you the evil MÄra?
MÄra thought he had been found out and returned to his original form.
The bhiká¹£u said to MÄra:
What do you fear me for, seeking?
MÄra said:
Seeing that the practitioner is diligent, I fear he will leave my realm, so I came to frighten him.
The bhiká¹£u said:

The reason I became a monk is to seek liberation from the world. I only want to see the Buddha's physical characteristics. Since the Buddha has passed away, there is no one who can see him. I heard that Mara can transform into the Buddha's body, so show me the Buddha's body, and I will no longer strive for progress.
Mara then transformed into the Buddha and stood before him. As he contemplated, he attained arhatship. The gods in the sky praised him immeasurably, but Mara repented and was immediately destroyed.
The Heavenly Emperor said to the monk:
These three people are praised by the gods, and it has not ceased until now.
The monk said to the Heavenly Emperor:
These three people clearly understand suffering and emptiness, so they have decayed their bodies.
I originally had no intention, but I was despised by others. I then went to seek the Way and escaped from the three realms. It is also wonderful that I have attained arhatship.
The gods replied:
Now return to the heavens and place the monk's head at the top.
Then the gods bowed and left.

Then the king of the country heard that the master of rock candy diligently practiced and attained the Way, so he went to pay homage, kowtowed and apologized, and eventually became the national teacher. He flourished the Three Jewels and brought peace to the country. The blessings and liberation he obtained were incalculable.
(6) Once there was a sick person whose many doctors could not cure him. He went straight to the king of the country. The king's name was Saheedan. He surrendered himself to the great king:
With compassion, please treat my illness.
The king then entrusted him to the masters and ordered them to treat his illness.
The doctors reported to the king:
This medicine cannot be obtained.
The king asked the masters:
What is the name of the medicine?
If one takes a soup made from the flesh of a person with the five poisons, one will be cured.
What are the five poisons?
First, a mind free from lust, second, a mind free from anger, third, a mind free from delusion, fourth, a mind free from jealousy, and fifth, a mind free from cruelty.
If there is such a person, their illness will be cured.
The king told the masters:
This person has come to me, but I alone do not have this poison.
He then cut flesh from his body to make soup for them, and the sick person's illness was cured after taking it, and they then gave rise to the MahÄyÄna.

(8) Speaking a parable for the family of impermanence.
There was a large tree, its fruit like a two-pint jar. When the fruit was about to ripen, a crow flew over and perched on a branch above. The fruit fell and killed the crow.
The tree spirit saw this and spoke a verse, saying:
The crow did not come seeking death, nor did the fruit fall for the crow's sake,
When the fruit ripens, the crow should die, it is the convergence of causes and conditions that makes it so.

When a person is in the world, the convergence of their sins and merits is fast or slow, there is no advance or retreat. A wise person does not resent receiving a crime or rejoice in receiving a blessing. Only then can they truly believe the Buddha's words, uphold them, and not be apart from them.

Within the three realms there are ninety-six kinds of paths. People of the world each revere what they serve, hoping for spiritual benefits. These lesser paths do not yet understand what is meritorious, how can they grasp virtue?

The reason for this is that they do not recognize the supreme brightness of the Three Jewels, they do not uphold the purity and truth of the five precepts, they do not have the profound insight of the eightæ­£, how can they save people?
Therefore, they are called thin fields.

Those who can respect the Three Jewels of the Buddha, understand the three periods of time, know the blessings of the heavenly hall, and examine the crimes of Mount Tai, who have utmost faith in the Three Jewels to block the three evil paths, who use the power of strong wisdom to dispel the ignorance of the three realms, and who cultivate the six pure divine waters to wash away the defilements of the six afflictions, are thus able to lightly spend their wealth and harm their body and speech, practicing equal giving to plant the roots of the future.
Giving one myriarchy, the reward is swift like an echo. Therefore it is said:
The great way is the good field of the three realms.
How can this be made clear?

In the past, King AÅ›oka once became a child. At that time, he encountered the Buddha and was overjoyed. He offered a little sand with utmost sincerity to the Buddha. Because of this blessing, he became a sage king, ruling over sixteen great countries and four hundred thousand li.
From this it can be seen that the Buddha is the best field.

In the past, the Buddha's younger brother Nanda, in the time of VipaÅ›yin Buddha, had the merit of bathing the saá¹…gha once, and his merits and virtues followed him. He was born in the ÅšÄkya clan, with a body adorned with the thirty-two marks, his divine appearance shining with golden color. Riding on the blessings of his past lives, he shared the same world as the Buddha, and diligently studied in the Way-place, thus attaining the six supernatural powers.
In the past, giving one thing still had vast rewards, how much more so for the present donors who are able to do many practices?
The practice of universal equality will surely lead to the honored title, and with increasing joy, widely deliver all.
(10) The Dharma says:
Defiling the mind for billions of eons is not decayed, and one is boiled in birth and death, only attaining the Way will it cease.

In the past, 500 years after the Buddha's nirvÄá¹‡a, there was a king who was diligent and courageous, rarely seen in the world. He made offerings to 60,000 Å›ramaá¹‡as for three months at one time, with sweet and fragrant delicacies, the best flavors in the world. The foremost elder monk was well-versed in the scriptures, exploring the past and understanding the present, and attained arhatship.

Four hundred and eighty li east of this country, there is a king who makes offerings to five hundred Brahmins, also to the utmost beauty of the world, making a hundred kinds of banners, flags, decorations, silks, cotton, gold, and various objects, with each banner worth five hundred taels of gold, using these skills and music to entertain them.
If there are those who can perform these skills, he will give them to them.

The poor people of various countries heard that the king of that country had these treasures, and each from the four directions gathered in a cloud, gathering five hundred people, taking the route through the monastery, each learning skills and wanting to obtain those treasures, but their food and supplies were exhausted and they could not reach their destination, so they went before the senior monk and sought to become monks.

The senior monk then observed them, and only saw that they were the servants of a virtuous family during the time of VipaÅ›yin Buddha, who once made food and drink for the monks and also heard the Dharma, and since then they have received blessings naturally in the heavens and among humans, and their blessings have now only been exhausted, but the Dharma words still remain, and these can be saved.
He then shaved their beards and hair and gave them the precepts. He was about to take them into the palace, but they returned, greatly delighted.

The teacher knew their thoughts and told them that this food should not be eaten recklessly. No one who lacks sincerity can eat this food. They will be reborn as cows, horses, slaves, or servants for many kalpas.
The five hundred newly ordained monks, hearing this, became terrified and intensified their efforts. In ninety days, they all attained arhatship.

The monks, having attained the Way, wanted to explain their past. They ran out and called, Come in through the king's gate and wrestle with me! The three poisons, the twelve links of dependent origination, the five aggregates, and the six sense bases, I have all overthrown them. Who can oppose me?
The assembly was startled, thinking, What is he saying?
The monk said:

We originally practiced skills to obtain precious rewards. As Å›ramaá¹‡as, we have attained arhatship. The various delusions in the three realms, we have all extinguished them. We have received the great teacher's grace and are infinitely happy.
Once upon a time, there were two brothers living together. They were very powerful, wealthy, and had immeasurable resources. When their parents passed away, they had no one to rely on.
Although they were brothers, their aspirations were different. The elder brother loved the Way and friendship;
The younger brother loved the family business, official rank, and salary, and was greedy for worldly glory and beauty.
They lived near the KukkutÄrÄma Monastery, not far from it.

The elder brother devoted himself to studying and receiving the scriptures, not paying attention to family affairs. The younger brother saw that his elder brother was not close to family matters and always resented him:

We are brothers, and our parents have passed away early. We have struggled to make a living, but he has abandoned the family business and chases after Å›ramaá¹‡as to listen to the Buddha's scriptures.
Can the Å›ramaá¹‡as give you clothes, wealth, and treasures?
The family is becoming poorer and resources are dwindling day by day. People laugh at him, calling him lazy and a waste, and the family will be destroyed.
As a son, one should establish achievements and continue the achievements and merits of one's parents without fail. Only then is one a filial son.
The elder brother replied:

The five precepts, ten wholesome [deeds], making offerings to the Three Jewels, practicing the six pÄramitÄs, sitting in meditation and contemplating concentration, and transforming one's relatives through the Way, this is filial piety.
The Way and worldly affairs are in opposition, this is a natural law. What the Way delights in, the world detests; what the world treasures, the Way considers worthless.
The wise and the foolish do not plan together, just as light and darkness cannot coexist.
Therefore, the wise leave darkness and follow light to attain the true Way.
What you delight in now is the self of suffering and affliction.
All is empty and false, without truth. Deluded and mistaken, one considers it to exist. How could one know the bitterness?
The younger brother harbored resentment and did not believe. The elder brother, seeing this, said:
You crave family affairs and consider wealth to be valuable. I delight in the Way of the scriptures and consider wisdom to be precious.

Now I want to abandon the household and take refuge in the field of merit. Life in the world is like a fleeting dust mote. Impermanence suddenly arrives, and I am bound by offenses. Therefore, I abandon the world, avoid danger, and seek peace.
The younger brother saw that his elder brother's intentions were directed towards the path, but there was no response.

The elder brother then left the household and became an ascetic. Day and night he diligently recited sutras and contemplated the Way. Single-mindedly sitting in meditation, he contemplated and reflected, never resting or slacking off. He then perfected the faculties, powers, and thirty-seven factors of enlightenment. Practicing in accordance with the sutra teachings, he attained the fruit of the Way.
He went to his younger brother and encouraged him to uphold the Dharma:
The five precepts and ten wholesome deeds are the basis for rebirth in the heavens. Generosity and learning are the foundation of the wisdom of the Way.
When the younger brother heard these words, his anger became even stronger. He immediately replied to his elder brother:

You should abandon it yourself. You are not close to the family business and destroy the family lineage. You can do this alone, but do not teach me. Quickly leave the door and do not interfere with my affairs.
The elder brother then left.
The younger brother greedily pursued family affairs, never resting, and had never settled his mind on the Dharma. Then, after his life ended, he fell into a cow, very fat and large.

Merchants bought it to carry salt to sell, going back and forth several times. The cow finally became emaciated and could not move forward. When going uphill, it collapsed in exhaustion and could not get up. The merchants whipped it, and it barely moved its head.
At that time, the elder brother was wandering and flying in the sky. Seeing this from afar, he immediately thought:
Knowing where it came from?
Observing its origin, he saw that it was his younger brother, and said to it:
Brother, the house, land, and fields that you cherished and enjoyed, where are they now?
And you have thrown yourself into the body of a cow.

He then used his spiritual power to illuminate his past life, and he immediately recognized his past actions, tears streaming down as he reproached himself for his unwholesomeness, stinginess, greed, and jealousy. He did not believe in the Buddha's teachings and disrespected the noble assembly. He indulged in his own desires and did not believe his brother's words. He went against the sacred teachings and acted arrogantly, thus falling into the body of an ox. Exhausted and weak, he regretted what had happened but there was nothing he could do about it.
His brother knew his thoughts and felt deeply saddened. He then explained the matter to the ox's owner, stating the details as they were:

This was originally my younger brother. He did not believe in the Three Jewels, turned his back on the truth and followed falsehood, was stingy and jealous, indulged himself, greedily sought without giving, and fell into the body of an ox. He is emaciated, weak, and pitiful. Now he is already old and exhausted, unfit for use. Fortunately, give him to me to save his remaining life.

When the merchants heard this, they immediately gave him to him. He then took the ox back to the temple, had him contemplate the Three Jewels, and fed him in a timely manner. When his life ended, he was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
At that time, the group of merchants each thought to themselves:

We diligently work for a living without being content, unable to give, and also do not serve the Dharma or understand the principles of the Way. Even if we die, we fear it will be the same and we will not escape this kind.

They then went out together, abandoned their wives and children, and gave up their cherished possessions. They went forth to become ascetics and diligently practiced without slacking, and all of them also attained the Way.

Considering this, worldly wealth and treasures do not benefit people. Serving and respecting the Three Jewels, cultivating the body and studying wisdom, extensively learning and practicing the Way, one will attain peace in life after life.

(12) In the past, in the country of Shravasti, there was a poor family. In the courtyard, there was a grape tree with several clusters of grapes. They thought of immediately giving them to the ascetics.
At that time, the king had previously invited them to a meal for a month. The poor family's strength and status were not as good.
The king strictly allowed them for a month, and then they were able to give to an ascetic. They held it and gave it to him, saying to the ascetic:
We have been thinking of giving for a month, and now we have finally fulfilled our wish.
The ascetic said to the upasika:
For one month.

The monk said:
But for one month you had the thought of giving, so it is a month.
There are eighteen things that are very difficult for people in the world:
First, it is difficult to encounter the Buddha's world;
Second, even if one encounters the Buddha, it is difficult to become a human being;ğŸ”½Third, even if one becomes a human being, it is difficult to be born in a central country;
Fourth, even if one is born in a central country, it is difficult to have a good family background;
Fifth, even if one has a good family background, it is difficult for the four limbs and six senses to be complete;
Sixth, even if the four limbs and six senses are complete, it is difficult to have wealth and property;ğŸ”½Seventh, even if one has wealth and property, it is difficult to have good friends;
Eighth, even if one has good friends, it is difficult to have wisdom;
Ninth, it is difficult for the rightly accomplished to obtain wisdom and a good mind;ğŸ”½Tenth, it is difficult for the rightly accomplished to obtain a good mind and be able to give in charity;
Eleventh, even if one is able to give in charity, it is difficult to wish to obtain a virtuous person with merit;
Twelfth, even if one rightly obtains a virtuous person with merit, it is difficult to go to their place;
Thirteenth, even if one rightly goes to their place, it is difficult to obtain what is appropriate;
Fourteenth, even if one rightly obtains what is appropriate, it is difficult to accept, listen, inquire, and speak the truth;
Sixteenth, even if one rightly obtains the truth, it is difficult to understand wisdom;
Seventeenth, even if one rightly obtains understanding of wisdom, it is difficult to be able to accept profound sutras of various difficulties;
These are the eighteen matters.
